channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Force’s Leader Signals No Letup in Bakhmut
item.description: The founder of Russia’s Wagner private army gave no indication of ending his campaign to seize Bakhmut, while urging the Kremlin to prepare for Ukrainian offensives. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers attending a religious service for a fallen comrade in Lviv, in western Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Rwanda Announces Release of Paul Rusesabagina, ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Hero
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, whose story inspired a Hollywood movie, was kidnapped by the Rwandan government and jailed. In a deal brokered by the U.S. and Qatar, he is to be set free.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Paul Rusesabagina at a hearing in Kigali, Rwanda, in 2021. His release will end two and a half years in captivity.

item.title: Rahul Gandhi, Leader of India’s Opposition to Modi, Disqualified From Parliament
item.description: The expulsion of Rahul Gandhi is a devastating blow to the once-powerful Indian National Congress party. He and several other politicians are now in jeopardy through India’s legal system.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Alex Travelli
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, the leader of the Indian National Congress Party, arriving at the New Delhi airport after his court appearance in Surat, India, on Thursday.

item.title: Israel’s Attorney General Says Netanyahu Broke Law With Judicial Intervention Pledge
item.description: Gali Baharav-Miara said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu created a conflict of interest by saying he would become more involved in pushing for a judicial overhaul while on trial for corruption.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, at a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Sunday, has vowed to proceed with a judicial overhaul that has divided the country.

item.title: Famed Antiwar Protester Was Once Cog in Russia’s Propaganda Machine
item.description: For 20 years, Marina Ovsyannikova worked for Russian state TV. What compelled her, shortly after Ukraine was invaded, to storm a live broadcast and tell viewers they were being lied to?
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine War Amputees Get New Limbs in U.S.
item.description: War has forced Ukraine to become skilled at treating amputees, but there are too many for its overtaxed medical workers. Some are finding their way to a prosthetics clinic in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: King Charles Postpones Trip to France Amid Unrest
item.description: The country has been rocked by strikes and protests over the past week after President Emmanuel Macron pushed through an increase in the legal retirement age.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Paris demonstrated on Thursday against President Emmanuel Macron and his effort to raise the legal retirement age to 64 from 62.

item.title: A Refuge for Russians and Ukrainians, Bali Rethinks Its Open-Door Policy
item.description: After multiple accounts of tourists behaving badly, its governor wants Russia and Ukraine to lose access to Indonesia’s visa-on-arrival program.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Nyimas Laula for The New York Times
item.media:description: Echo Beach in Bali, Indonesia. Bali residents have found themselves at odds with the practices of some of the Ukrainians and Russians who’ve fled their home countries for refuge in Bali.

item.title: U.S. Due Diligence Firm Says China Detained Its Employees
item.description: Five Chinese nationals were taken away last Monday, and the company, which does corporate investigations, and its law firm have been unable to contact them.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: The closed office of the Mintz Group in Beijing on Friday. The company said it has not been able to contact five Chinese employees since they were detained on Monday.

item.title: Canada Grew by a Record 1 Million People From Immigration
item.description: The country’s growth was fueled almost entirely by newcomers, as the federal government pushes more immigration to plug labor shortages.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants arriving at the Roxham Road border crossing in February in Quebec.

item.title: Ukrainian Commanders Frustrated With Slow Pace of Western Tank Deliveries
item.description: For now, they are holding on with inferior Soviet-era tanks, but relish the idea of taking on the Russians with modern Western battle tanks.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Servicemen from the Adam Battalion preparing to head toward the front line near Bakhmut, Ukraine

item.title: An Australian River Choking on Fish Corpses, and a Community Full of Anger
item.description: It’s the latest clash over a river basin in New South Wales, Australia, in an arid land where social, economic and environmental interests collide over water issues.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Michaela Skovranova
item.media:description: Millions of dead fish floating along parts of the lower Darling River in Menindee, Australia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Centuries of Stargazing Leave Jesuit Names Written in the Heavens
item.description: The latest list of approved labels for asteroids includes nods to three more scholars of the order, as well as a pope, challenging the idea that science and religion make awkward partners.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brother Guy Consolmagno, director of the Vatican’s observatory near Rome, in 2017. The observatory, or Specola Vaticana, has roots dating to Pope Gregory XIII in the 16th century.

item.title: China Denies Pressuring Companies Like TikTok to Spy on Users
item.description: China’s foreign ministry rebuffed claims made by U.S. lawmakers at a hearing on Thursday that TikTok could be a tool of surveillance for the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:description: Shou Chew, the chief executive of TikTok, testifying before the House Energy and Commerce Committee in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Free Speech (or Not) at Stanford
item.description: A federal judge spoke at Stanford Law School. Chaos ensued.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Stanford University.

item.title: In Held v. Montana, Young People Sue Montana Over Use of Fossil Fuels
item.description: Sixteen young Montanans have sued their state, arguing that its support of fossil fuels violates the state Constitution.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Matthew Hamon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Badge, left, and Lander Busse, teenage plaintiffs in a lawsuit against the state of Montana saying it violated the state Constitution that guarantees “the right to a clean and healthful environment.”

item.title: North Korea Says It Tested a Nuclear-Capable Underwater Attack Drone
item.description: Such a test would be a first for Kim Jong-un’s weapons program. But there was no independent confirmation that it had happened.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage of North Korea’s reported drone test, featuring a state media image of the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, on a screen in a Seoul train station.

item.title: Melbourne Art and Design, Past and Present
item.description: Two exhibitions in Melbourne — “Radical Utopia” and “Melbourne Now” — trace the city’s art and design from the 1980s to the present.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: That Missing Trump Portrait? Found, Next to Some Old Yoga Mats.
item.description: After a tip, The Times located a portrait of Donald Trump given to him by El Salvador’s president and that Democrats were eager to account for. It was propped up in an obscure spot in a Trump hotel.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Ana Maria Hanssen
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Francisco Antonio López Benavides, who painted a portrait of former president Donald J. Trump, showing a detail of the painting.

item.title: As Zelensky Visits Kherson, World Bank Says Ukraine Needs $411 Billion to Rebuild
item.description: The bank released a significantly higher figure as European Union leaders approved plans to provide Kyiv with one million artillery shells over the next 12 months.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston, Victoria Kim and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Ukrainian president’s office on Thursday showed Volodymyr Zelensky during a visit to the Kherson region. He said he saw evidence of rebuilding during his trip.

item.title: Track and Field Keeps Ban on Russia and Belarus, Adding to Debate on Olympics
item.description: Another similar ban by the council that oversees ice hockey shows the issue has not waned.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: From left, Sebastian Coe, the president of World Athletics, Jon Ridgeon, the group’s chief executive, and Rune Andersen, the leader of the group’s Russia task force, in Rome in November.

item.title: American Hopes for Canadian Military Leadership in Haiti Likely to Be Dashed
item.description: The United States had hoped that its neighbor would lead a major intervention, but Canada lacks resources and is skeptical of its value.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Canadian special forces soldiers with the Haitian police at the Port-au-Prince airport in 2004, after the overthrow of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

item.title: U.S. and Canada Reach an Agreement on Diverting Asylum Seekers
item.description: The deal, reached just before President Biden arrived in Canada for an official visit, allows both countries to reduce a surge in migration.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Ian Austen
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada greeting each other in Ontario on Thursday while their wives, Jill Biden and Sophie Grégoire Trudeau, do likewise. The two North American leaders are said to have a “Justin and Joe” relationship.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: U.S. Lawmakers Blast TikTok’s C.E.O.
item.description: Also, a World Bank estimate on the cost to rebuild Ukraine and a prison sentence for India’s opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Spain’s Prime Minister to Visit Xi in China to Discuss Ukraine
item.description: China has been trying to build support for its proposal to start peace talks, but Ukraine’s allies hold that its call for an immediate cease-fire would only help Russia consolidate territorial gains.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista
item.media:description: Primer Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain says he intends to discuss Russia’s invasion of Ukraine with President Xi Jinping of China during a visit to Beijing next week.

item.title: Slovakia Makes Its First Delivery of Pledged Soviet-Era Fighter Jets to Ukraine
item.description: The arrival of the aging MIG-29s is not expected to significantly change battlefield dynamics, and the planes will most likely be used for spare parts for Ukraine’s own Soviet-era jets.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: A MIG-29 fighter jet flying near an air base in Malacky, Slovakia, in August of last year.

item.title: The U.K.’s Wave of Strikes Explained: Why Is It Ending?
item.description: For months, labor disputes rattled Britain, disrupting transportation, the mail and even medical procedures. Now, tensions seem to have eased.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathering in Parliament Square in London to rally in support of striking Royal Mail workers in December. Though few of the labor disputes from last year are fully settled, agreements are taking shape in many.

item.title: Netanyahu Digs In on Court Overhaul, in the Face of Mass Protests
item.description: Amid a national crisis over a planned judicial overhaul, Israel’s Parliament approved a bill making it much harder to remove a prime minister from office.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Tel Aviv on Thursday protesting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s plans to overhaul Israel’s judicial system.

item.title: New Day of Strikes in France as Pension Anger Persists
item.description: The tensions started when President Emmanuel Macron raised the retirement age to 64, and the anger shows no sign of abating.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Paris on Thursday. It was the ninth day of nationwide strikes and protests over French pension changes.

item.title: The Threat of TikTok
item.description: U.S. officials say TikTok is a national security risk. They’re trying to turn it into their advantage.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson

item.title: Rahul Gandhi Is Sentenced in Defamation Case
item.description: Rahul Gandhi, who leads the main opposition party, received a two-year sentence for a comment in 2019 criticizing Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi speaking in Jammu, India, in January. Mr. Gandhi is the de facto leader of the Indian National Congress and has been trying to revive the party’s fortunes.

item.title: West African Commandos Train to Battle Terrorists by Land and Sea
item.description: As terrorists move south through the Sahel, the Pentagon’s annual Flintlock exercise reinforced the rule of law in a region roiled by coups.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Kenny Holston
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The waterborne mission included this year reflects rising concern about security in the Gulf of Guinea.

item.title: Migration Tops Agenda as Biden Meets With Trudeau During Canada Visit
item.description: As migration has swelled at the U.S.-Canada border, the two countries plan to announce a deal to allow them both to turn back asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada during the Summit of the Americas last year. Migration will be a key topic of discussion when Mr. Biden visits Canada this week.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Legal cases involving Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Ukrainian government, Volodymyr Zelensky met soldiers near Bakhmut.

item.title: Zelensky Makes Morale-Boosting Trip to Bakhmut
item.description: The Ukrainian leader also condemned a deadly Russian missile attack against an apartment building in Zaporizhzhia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Valerie Hopkins, Enjoli Liston and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Ukrainian government, President Volodymyr Zelensky met soldiers on Wednesday near Bakhmut.

item.title: The DeSantis Foreign Policy: Hard Power, but With a High Bar
item.description: The Florida governor has never been the internationalist that some old-guard Republicans wanted or imagined him to be. A close reading of his record reveals how he might lead the U.S. abroad.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Kitty Bennett
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has worked to align himself with the increasingly nationalistic Republican base, which he will need to win the 2024 presidential primary if he runs.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Raises Interest Rates
item.description: Also, China and Russia grow closer and the U.S. waits for news of a possible Donald Trump indictment.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a press conference to announce a new interest rate decision, in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday.

item.title: Prince William Visits Poland to Thank Troops Supporting Ukraine
item.description: He met with President Andrzej Duda on the second day of his visit to Poland.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Prince William met with the Polish defense minister, Mariusz Blaszczak, and visited British and Polish troops stationed in Rzeszow, Poland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ship Owned by U.S. Navy Tips Over at Edinburgh Port, Injuring Dozens
item.description: A research vessel once owned by the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen and now by the U.S. Navy became dislodged while docked. The cause of the accident was under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Petrel, a 250-foot-long research vessel, toppled over at a shipyard in Edinburgh on Wednesday. The ship had been fitted to take part in expeditions to explore shipwrecks around the globe.

item.title: U.K. Defends Sending Ukraine Weapons with Depleted Uranium
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia falsely claimed the material had a “nuclear component.” Many armies, including Russia’s, use it in weapons.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and John Ismay
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin on Tuesday, following talks with President Xi Jinping of China.

item.title: In Paris, Protests Over Pension Law Take On a Hint of Menace
item.description: Peaceful solidarity alternates with the threat of violence, and all of France waits to see which way the standoff will turn.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Protesters gathering for a demonstration in the Place de la Concorde in Paris last week. Unofficial protests have spread since the government pushed through an unpopular pension law.

item.title: U.K. Lawmakers Approve Stormont Brake in Northern Ireland Brexit Deal
item.description: An important element of the agreement known as the Windsor Framework, a Brexit provision negotiated with the European Union, was roundly endorsed in the British Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The strong backing for the measure was good news for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has championed the broader trade deal.

item.title: Geothermal Power, Cheap and Clean, Could Help Run Japan. So Why Doesn’t It?
item.description: For decades, new plants have been blocked by powerful local interests, the owners of hot spring resorts, that say the sites threaten a centuries-old tradition.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Macron Denounces Violent Protests in France
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, in his first remarks since pushing through a rise in the retirement age, was firm and unapologetic.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke on Wednesday in a televised interview with two journalists, his first remarks since pushing through a rise in the retirement age.

item.title: Boris Johnson Faces Inquiry Over Whether He Lied to U.K. Parliament
item.description: Boris Johnson told a powerful committee that his statements over parties at his office were “made in good faith.” His political future may be at stake.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The former British prime minister Boris Johnson, center, on his way to to attend a hearing that could result in his suspension from Parliament, or even his ejection.

item.title: The I.C.C.’s Arrest Warrant for Putin is More Than ‘Just Symbolic’
item.description: A different way to think about justice & accountability
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Wednesday in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: Uganda Passes Strict Anti-Gay Bill That Imposes Death Penalty for Some
item.description: The legislation, which now goes to the president, also calls for life in prison for anyone engaging in gay sex. Policies to stifle L.G.B.T.Q. rights have been on the rise in several African nations.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ugandan legislators debated the anti-gay bill in Parliament in the capital, Kampala, on Tuesday. It passed by a vote of 387 to 2.

item.title: In a Brother Act With Putin, Xi Reveals China’s Fear of Containment
item.description: Instead of focusing on a solution to the war in Ukraine, the Chinese leader’s visit to Moscow reinforced China and Russia’s shared opposition to American dominance.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media on Tuesday showing the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, who was greeted with pomp and pageantry on his visit to Moscow.

item.title: The Fed’s Unpleasant Choice
item.description: What’s worse: More inflation or more turmoil?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Federal Reserve building on Tuesday.

item.title: Russian Faced Prison Time for Instagram Post About War in Ukraine
item.description: The case of Olesya Krivtsova, a Russian student who ended up on the Kremlin’s official terrorist list, has underscored the perils of using social media to criticize the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olesya Krivtsova in court in Russia. She said she later fled the country because she did not believe her chances of being exonerated were high amid a broader Kremlin crackdown on free speech.

item.title: At Al Aqsa Mosque, Shards of Stained Glass Tell a Story of Conflict
item.description: Artisans at the contested Jerusalem holy site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, complain of Israeli interference with their work and face a constant struggle to keep up with repairs after violence flares.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renovations in September on a window in the Qibli Mosque, one of two main structures inside the Aqsa compound.

item.title: As Haiti’s Police Retreat, Gangs Take Over Much of the Capital
item.description: Even wealthier areas in the capital, Port-au-Prince, are no longer immune to violence as gangs attack police officers and destroy police stations.
item.dc:creator: Andre Paultre and Chris Cameron
item.media:description: People walk past members of the Haitian National Police in March as they attempt to repel gangs in a neighborhood near the Presidential Palace in Port-au-Prince.

item.title: U.K. Inflation Swings Upward, to 10.4 Percent
item.description: Prices in Britain reversed a recent downward trend, rising 10.4 percent over the year through February.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oxford Street shoppers in London. The Bank of England has raised rates nearly four percentage points in an effort to stem high inflation.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Closer ties between Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: During an appearance with President Xi Jinping of China, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said China’s plan could be taken as a basis for peaceful settlement in Ukraine. Kyiv’s Western allies have criticized the framework as unreasonable.

item.title: Xi and Putin Bind China and Russia’s Economies Further, Despite War in Ukraine
item.description: On the second day of the Chinese leader’s state visit in Moscow, Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin declared an enduring economic partnership, in an effort to insulate their countries from punitive Western measures.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media on Tuesday shows President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Grand Kremlin Palace in Moscow.

item.title: Pulling the Plug on TikTok Will Be Harder Than It Looks
item.description: The tensions over the Chinese-owned social media app will come to a head on Thursday, when the company’s chief executive testifies on Capitol Hill.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:description: The TikTok app has 150 million users in the United States, but some fear that its Chinese parent company might give Beijing access to American users’ data.

item.title: Report of Wuhan Market Samples Found Covid and Raccoon Dog Genetic Material
item.description: In a much-anticipated study, experts described a swab that was positive for the coronavirus and contained loads of genetic material from raccoon dogs.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Security at the entrance to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan on Jan. 11, 2020.

item.title: A ‘Rocking Chair Rebellion’: Seniors Call On Banks to Dump Big Oil
item.description: Older climate activists gathered in cities around the country for a day of action targeting banks that finance fossil fuel projects.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Craig Hudson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two protesters outside a Chase Bank in Washington, part of a demonstration organized by Third Act, a group for older climate activists, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China, Japan Divided on Ukraine
item.description: Also, an I.M.F. loan to Sri Lanka and the Japan-U.S. final in the World Baseball Classic.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: This photograph released by Russian state media showing Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping attending a reception at the Kremlin in Moscow on Tuesday.
